data.text:
Alternative (Alt) Text is an essential part of making content accessible. When adding images, charts, icons or other graphic elements, alt text should be added to ensure your content will be accessible to all users.

What is Alt Text?

Alt Text is a brief text description of an image.

Alt Text is read by screen readers (or other assistive tech) to provide information about the image's purpose to the reader.

Alt text should not just describe what the image contains, but instead should provide context on how the image relates to the page content.

Alt Text Best Practices

Keep it short, usually 1-2 sentences. Don’t overthink it.

Consider key elements of why you chose this image for your document, instead of describing every little detail.

No need to say “image of”or “picture of.”

But, do say if it’s a logo, illustration, painting, or cartoon.

Don’t duplicate text that’s adjacent in the document or website

End the alt text sentence with a period.

How to Write Alt Text

Images

When adding images, consider why you have chosen that particular image and what you want it to convey.

Example: This image will be used on a page about track tryouts.

Poor Alt Text: "Harvard Runners."

Useful Alt Text: "Harvard Stadium with two lone runners bounding up the steps."

Logos

Alt text for logos should reference the image's purpose. They may or may not include the word logo.

Example: This is Harvard's classic shield used on many branded materials.

Poor Alt text: "Harvard."

Useful Alt text: "Harvard's Crimson Veritas Shield."

Icons

Alt text for icons should be the equivalent to the information intended by the icon, such as “Download PDF” or “Visit our Facebook Page.”

Example: This printer icon will be used on a page with a schedule of events.

Poor Alt Text: "Printer icon."

Useful Alt Text: "Print the Event Schedule."

Images as Links

If the image is being used to link to another page, the alt text should describe what will happen when the image is clicked (rather than what it looks like).

Example: This question mark links to a help page and is intended to encourage users to click if they need support.

Poor Alt Text: "Question Mark."

Useful Alt Text: "Contact Support."

Additional Benefits of Adding Alt Text

It is indexed by search engines.

It also will display if the image fails to load, as in this example of a missing image:

Testing

Use testing tools to hide images and display their alt text. Does the page make sense with the images hidden, replaced by their text alternatives?

Do all linked images meaningfully describe their action rather than their appearance?
